p: Transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the agent causing COVID-19, is driven by virus-containing droplets released from the upper airways and aerosols that can float, dependent on the airflow, for a prolonged period in the environment ( Meselson, 2020). Aerosols can be spread by just breathing, while droplets originate from speaking, shouting, sneezing, and coughing as well as from singing and playing wind instruments ( Zhang et al., 2020, Zhen-Dong et al., 2020, Asadi et al., 2019). Of great importance are super-spreading events, which are infection clusters constituting effective chains of SARS-CoV-2 transmission. For instance, such superspreading events have been observed in Hong Kong ( Adam et al., 2020), at religious mass events in Iran ( Mubarak and Zin, 2020) and choir rehearsals in the US ( Hamner et al., 2020), where singing contributed to a maximum emission of droplets and aerosols and, thus, to successful transmission ( Asadi et al., 2019).
